displayed_text: Family Member: So he’ll go downstairs and get his blood drawn. Doctor: Yes. All right. So let me make a copy of this though for you for your records. Family Member: We’re very thankful for meeting you. And how thorough you are. And how comfortable, you make you know, it makes me feel comfortable. Doctor: Thank you. Thank you. I always tell me I'm not happy that we met under the circumstances- Patient: Yes. Doctor: - but try make the best of it. Family Member: Yes, yes. And your knowledge you know. You have so much knowledge, you know, different trials and medicines Doctor: You'll help me, you know my family is not in medicine. Family Member: Oh really? Doctor: But sometimes I get accused of speaking in too much medical lingo. Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: So if you don't, because a lot of my friends are doctors obviously.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: But my expectation is just to be very honest is that yes, there will be some degree of PSA reduction. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And it may delay the need for hormone therapy for another six months from now with another twelve months from now. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: But I kind of do think that a hormone therapy is sort of inevitable for you. Um the other question that you asked was about using chemotherapy. I presume that you’re asking whether that was either given by itself or maybe in combination with hormone therapy like as a clumped – double therapy. And that we have also done - there have been trials to support that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you know the clinical trials and also the clinical experience do suggest that when you combine standard hormone therapy with chemotherapy or standard hormone therapy with newer type of hormone therapy called (novel) Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. But but again, I don’t want you to go into that thinking that it’s going to increase the chance of a cure. The cure rate is still you know pretty close to zero percent and that it increases the length of time that that systemic therapy works. Patient: Okay. And see, that that that’s my concern at this point. Um you know um you think in terms of the reason I keep pushing hormonal so far back is because I know that’s a proven method - Doctor: Yeah. It is -

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It turns out that the genetic material of the cancer cell, which is called the DNA. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - in order for that cancer cell to be able to replicate itself, to cause you know two cells from one and then four cells, eight cells, it needs to be able to replicate its DNA and then replicate itself after that. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And it turns out when you give high doses of testosterone in the setting where that cell has previously been in a low testosterone environment - Patient: Okay. Doctor: It causes the DNA molecules in the cell, the genetic material of the cancer cell, to break into smaller pieces. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the DNA molecule basically shatters into these small pieces and that damage is so catastrophic that the cell is unable to fix those DNA breaks and because the DNA molecule has been broken up into small little pieces, that cell can’t replicate itself and it dies. Patient: Oh! Doctor: So that’s the theoretical mechanism. Patient: Uh huh.

Patient: Yes. It is. It’s the same thing. Doctor: Yes. So I would say, uh, I think that’s not going to work. That would be my- Patient: Yeah. They don’t, they don’t, they don’t- Doctor: From what I know. From what I know about it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, so this is what the compound is. It’s called, amygdalin. And this is, it has cyanide. There it is, cyanide. Patient: Right. Doctor: And, supposedly, this gets removed from this, what is it? Some sugar. Uh, but in humans, it just, we just don’t, we don’t have that enzyme. Patient: The enzyme to break it down? Doctor: Yeah. So- Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, yeah, the HIV, I don’t, I can, I’ll look again, but the last time I, there’s no trials that I know of that are in prostate cancer.

Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: And that’s, and the data is clear. Everything else we’re doing you have to do is you know unmeasurable. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Because if you do the radiation and hormones you have a fifty/fifty shot at being cured. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So if the cancer never comes back you don’t know if what we did helped or not. Right, I admit that. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Right. Family Member: I’m so sorry. Doctor: And if it does come back, we don’t know if will stay a little longer. Family Member: Right. Doctor: We just don’t know.

Patient: All right. Sounds good. Doctor: Yes. Is this a? He can do a new activation code? Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Doctor: Sounds good. Other questions for me? Patient: No, I think I understand where we're going. Right now, we haven't any delineated factors that we have to charge in any direction so. Doctor: Good. So there are study options and then we have to do usual care then Patient: Right. Okay. Yeah sounds good. Doctor: You’ll get your orders to get your blood work, the Aximun scan maybe at our baby site, you know. Patient: Okay Doctor: So, we'll get into a radiology schedule- Patient: All right. Doctor: -uh as we need it, if I find more out by the end of the week, but how to get it scheduled. I’ll let you know.

Patient: Yeah I took some ah I took my pain medicine… Doctor: Pain medicine. Patient: …before I got here. Doctor: Any better though since we started the chemo? Did you notice any difference in your appetite in your – how you’re feeling? I still feel kind of you know I just had heat flashes and all of that, but the pills that you gave me. Patient: They make me crazy. I was just… Doctor: I think, I think also I started you on the Prednisone remember for your along with the Chemo. Patient: Right. Doctor: So that one, let’s back off first of all to once a day. Patient: Oh, don’t… take it just once? Doctor: Just once in the morning. Patient: I’m gonna need a refill. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I think so.

Family Member: You might not know what’s making you feel – Doctor: Exactly. So I want to just poison you one thing at a time. Family Member: Poison (chuckles) Doctor: Okay? Patient: And the V___ Patient: I was seeing a doctor V___ in O____ in D____. Doctor: That’s him. Patient: That’s him. Doctor: We got him here. Patient: Oh he’s here now. Doctor: He’s here now. So he’s the go-to guy to get that process through. It goes through his group. Okay? So my suggestion is that we just have a discussion with him about side effects and pros and cons and what not as the next step. In the meantime you’re taking more pain medicine, right? Regularly. Family Member: I can’t – he’s like a little child “time for your medicine, are you going to take it?” Doctor: I know.

Patient: Yeah. That works for me. Doctor: Yeah. Blood work, Aximun scan. You're not on MyChart? Patient: I tried to get on MyChart, but the little number that he sent me, died or whatever. Doctor: Yeah, but I can we can print out a new one for you today. Patient: Okay good. Doctor: And then if you can just MyChart message me your email- Patient: Yes. Doctor: -but as to you know, my Aximun scan is scheduled for this day. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then I can add you in for the following Tuesday. Patient: All right. Sounds good. Doctor: Without knowing when that schedule, there's probably not anybody there. So we'll see what that looks like.

Family Member: …than chemo, correct? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Okay. Does any others have xxx]? Doctor: I think and since his cancer has shown us over the years that it was very sensitive to hormonal therapies, I would advocate doing that – Family Member: Right. Doctor: - unless I see you know big huge lymph nodes or some xxx] in there that I’m majorly concerned about. Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The other option again for lymph nodes of a specific size and the size limitation is more because one of the studies we have requires the smallest size of the lymph node to be one point five centimeter or higher. And that is uh a combination of a medication called Cabozantinib with an immune therapy. So that combination I think I would strongly recommend looking at if you have enough disease that needs treatment. Obviously if there’s… Patient: Are you gonna be able to find that out today? Doctor: I’m hoping to, yes. So that’s why I said let’s try and get some preliminary information on your CAT scans because that is going to be the key decision maker. Patient: More so than a bone? Doctor: I think the bone scan the problem is your report compared it to I don’t know a scan done years ago, because in between all the bone scans you had were here, they were not up there…

Patient: Oh. Doctor: That’s where the cohorts come up to six. Patient: Come up to six. Okay. So, so, it can - alright. Doctor: I’m willing to accept one out of three people having trouble. Um. And so, if we see one out of three, we don’t know whether it is actually more, so we add six. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor: So, if two out of six get into trouble, then we stop. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But, if only one out of six, then we keep going. Patient: Alright. So, if I were to join this and they kinda get shut down, I can’t go back to what I’m doing right now then. Doctor: We can use Enzalutamide, Patient: Okay. Doctor: -but you can’t use the TGF-A drug Patient: Okay. And we don’t know what is, uh, is keeping the PSA level at ten. It, it, it’s, it’s not going -

Family Member: Oh. Sounds interesting. Doctor: It’s, it’s, you know, on one of those Zagat books and stuff. Family Member: Right. Doctor: It’s just, they do creative things. It’s not your standard mac and cheese. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: You like it? Family Member: Right. Doctor: So you’re not into it, but it, it just tastes really good. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And then there’s the H___ C___, which is also pretty good. Family Member: I’ve heard of it. Okay. Doctor: Right across the street.

Patient: Then, why do I keep getting stuck? Doctor: Uh, because - Doctor: You know, we’re about ready to start, you know, a trial or a drug, uh, you know, so, Patient: So, you need that base, a current baseline? Doctor: Yeah, we wanna know where you are as we get started. Patient: And that’s understandable. Doctor: It’s your turn. I want you to do that for me. Patient: Yeah, no, you explained it, someone explained it that there’s - when chemo starts - it’ll be a blood test prior the chemo and a blood test after. And, uh, the leaving the timings out of it because I don’t really recall. And then, then roughly a week before the next cycle, there’ll be a blood test, then the chemo, and then, we’ll say within a week, I guess it’s another blood test. And that’s to keep an eye on, uh, all of these numbers? The blood cell or the white counts, etc.? Doctor: Yeah, I mean, so chemotherapy certainly can drop your blood counts and put you at risk for infection. Uh, so, we wanna make sure that, uh, how low is it to sort of - if you did have a fever, are we worried; are we not worried? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, and before we give you your next dose, we need to make sure that your counts have recovered (cell phone alert) Patient: Okay. (softly) Doctor: So, those are all, you know, the typical thing is with chemotherapy, you see myself or C__, you know, one day, and then we pick a day, the next day or the next day, to come in and get the chemotherapy. So, we’re really trying to do a safety evaluation that yes, it’s safe. Okay?

Patient: It varies. Like the night before I didn’t wake up until like four and then some nights it might be every two hours or couple of hours. Doctor: hm mmm, yep, yeah, Do you feel like you empty when you pee Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: or do you feel there’s a little more in there? Patient: There’s more because you go ahead and pee the full stream then you stop then you, it’s bogged down. Doctor: Yep, Yep, So, do me a favor. Like after seven p.m. at night don’t drink fluid; Patient: Okay. Doctor: don’t drink water, don’t drink tea, don’t drink coffee, don’t drink juice, don’t drink milk, don’t drink anything. After dinner, just done. One, that will allow you to sleep because I think your prostate is acting up, it’s too big which means it’s blocking the way of the pee and then what happens is you pee but there’s stuff left over but your body doesn’t know it until just a little bit more accumulates in there and also your bladder is like oh, I was this full and now I’m this full, okay, I got to pee again and when you’re laying down you pee a lot easier because then your whole body is trying to recalibrate and what’s happening. So, at that point you got to pee some more. So, if you give it less reason to pee which means you don’t have enough fluid on board then you won’t pee because there’s not fluid to put through. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you do me a favor and do that. I’ll work on getting your CAT scan and your bone scan set up and then we’ll figure out the next step. My thinking is that it probably - I’m going to shoot for the ah vaccine because once that’s done we don’t go back to it and then we just sort of put that and say done and then we move on to the other stuff. What do you think of that? Because if that sounds okay what takes forever is insurance Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: so if you’re kind of conceptually okay with that then I’m going to have J____, you know J____ who is our nurse, if you don’t know J____, you’re gonna know J____ in a minute. Patient: Is that the one that took the…

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::strongly agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Nah you can keep Dr. V____. Doctor: Well hopefully it will respond to the second one, the one that we use if people are resistant to this particular chemo that you’re on. Patient: What, what is this one gonna be? Doctor: What is what? Patient: This chemo, what you, what you gonna suggest? Doctor: So this is a medication called Cabazitaxel. I’ll give you information and the name and everything. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know the paperwork that we usually do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The, it, the biggest side effect can be dropping of blood counts. So what you’re gonna have to do… Doctor: No. The best way to prevent it is we will give you a shot the second day, okay, the day after your chemo to um help prevent the blood counts from dropping. Patient: So this will be the last chemo? Doctor: Yes.
